metadata.title: Differentially Private k-Means with Constant Multiplicative Error
metadata.author: Uri Stemmer, Haim Kaplan
metadata.journal: Conference on Neural Information Processing Systems
metadata.abstract: We design new differentially private algorithms for the Euclidean k-means problem, both in the centralized model and in the local model of differential privacy. In both models, our algorithms achieve significantly improved error guarantees than the previous state-of-the-art. In addition, in the local model, our algorithm significantly reduces the number of interaction rounds. Although the problem has been widely studied in the context of differential privacy, all of the existing constructions achieve only super constant approximation factors. We present—for the first time—efficient private algorithms for the problem with constant multiplicative error. Furthermore, we show how to modify our algorithms so they compute private coresets for k-means clustering in both models.

highlights: In particular center based clustering, are central problems in unsupervised learning

We present the first polynomial time differentially private algorithm for the Euclidean k-means problem with constant multiplicative error, while essentially keeping the additive error the same as in previous state-of-the-art results
We present a new local model of differential privacy algorithm for the k-means achieving constant multiplicative error
Balcan et al constructed a differentially private algorithm for identifying a set of candidate centers Y based on the Johnson–Lindenstrauss transform [23]
We show that our techniques result in new constructions for private coresets for k-means and k-medians, both for the centralized and for the local model of differential privacy

In every iteration, Step 2a satisfies differential privacy by the properties of Algorithm Private-Centers, and we use the following technique for arguing about Step 2b: Let X be an ordered data domain and let A be a differentially private algorithm that operates on a multiset of m elements from X

We present the first polynomial time differentially private algorithm for the Euclidean k-means problem with constant multiplicative error, while essentially keeping the additive error the same as in previous state-of-the-art results
We present a new local model of differential privacy algorithm for the k-means achieving constant multiplicative error
Balcan et al constructed a differentially private algorithm for identifying a set of candidate centers Y based on the Johnson–Lindenstrauss transform [23]
We show that the weighted set of candidate centers can be post-processed to obtain an approximation to the k-means of the input points

summary: In particular center based clustering, are central problems in unsupervised learning.

The starting point of our work is the observation that by combining ideas from three previous works [18, 6, 29] we can obtain a differentially private k-means algorithm with constant multiplicative error, but with a relatively large additive error which is polynomial in n.
Balcan et al constructed a differentially private algorithm for identifying a set of candidate centers Y based on the Johnson–Lindenstrauss transform [23].

Nissim and Stemmer [29] presented an improved algorithm for the 1-cluster problem which, when combined with the reduction of Feldman et al, gives a private k-means algorithm with multiplicative error O(k).

By combining this with the techniques of Balcan et al and Gupta et al for privately choosing k centers out of Y , we get our new construction for k-means in the centralized model of differential privacy.
We show that our techniques result in new constructions for private coresets for k-means and k-medians, both for the centralized and for the local model of differential privacy.

There exists an (ε, δ)-differentially private algorithm that takes a database S containing n points from the d-dimensional ball B(0, Λ), and outputs a subset D ⊆ Y of size |D| = k s.t. with probability at least
The algorithm privately identifies set of polynomially many candidate centers that contains a subset of k candidate centers with low k-means cost.

If during some iteration i we have that all of Pj∗ is contained in our current set of input points, Si, and if |Pj∗| ≥ w · ni0.1, a center for Sj∗ is discovered in the ith iteration by the properties of Private-Centers.

For i ∈ [log log n] we denote by Ai ⊆ S and Bi ⊆ S the subset of input points whose cluster is assigned to a center during the ith iteration in the comments after Step 2a and after Step 2b, respectively.

In every iteration, Step 2a satisfies differential privacy by the properties of Algorithm Private-Centers, and we use the following technique for arguing about Step 2b: Let X be an ordered data domain and let A be a differentially private algorithm that operates on a multiset of m elements from X.

There is an (ε, δ)-differentially private algorithm that, given a database S containing n points in the d-dimensional ball B(0, Λ), identifies with probability 1 − β a (γ, η)-approximation for the k-means of S, where γ = O(1) and η = poly log(n), log(
headline: We show how to modify our algorithms so they compute private coresets for k-means clustering in both models
